results.title: Cosmic zoom
results.brief_description:
From the top of the Empire State Building to the edge of the known universe, this breath-taking three-minute video animation sequence was produced for a television documentary series. Using spatial data over a huge range of scales, the sequence was produced using six different renderers, developed specially to deal with planetary surfaces, atmospheres, stars, individual galaxies and groups of galaxies. Aerial photography was combined with high-resolution and global satellite imagery of the Earth. Planetary imagemaps of the Moon, Mars and Saturn were developed from the Clementine, Viking and Voyager missions. The rings of Saturn were derived from Voyager’s occultation experiment and Voyager itself is depicted as a 3D model heading up out of the plane of the solar system. The nearest stars are portrayed with their correct relative positions, magnitude and colour, extracted from astronomical catalogues.

The only object not based directly on scientific observations is our own Milky Way galaxy, half of which is obscured from view from Earth by the dense galactic nucleus. Our galaxy and the neighbouring Andromeda galaxy were rendered using specially-written software which models the 3D distribution of tens of millions of individual stars and clouds of light-blocking dust, using telescopic images as a template. These and the other galaxies were portrayed in their correct relative positions, size, morphological type and dominant colour. By the end of the sequence we are looking back, across chains and walls of galaxies, from the edge of the known universe.

results.title: Coronary counter attack
results.brief_description: Outlines heart disease risk factors, and argues that aerobic exercise will reduce these risks. Gives guidelines for such selected activities as jogging, swimming, bicycling, walking, rope jumping and cross-country skiing. Featuring Dr Kenneth H. Cooper.

results.title: Coping with stress
results.brief_description: Outlines the factors that cause body stress; how the body reacts to stress; the kinds of problems that are stress-related; and ways of coping with stress such as exercise, relaxation, meditation and biofeedback. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Coping with life...on the run
results.brief_description: Dr George Sheehan, cardiologist and marathoner, and other runners from many walks of life, attest that fitness leads to an improved self-image and a more productive performance in daily jobs and professions. A motivational film stating that a good level of physical fitness is essential to being able to cope with everyday challenges. Produced in co-operation with the President’s Council on Physical Fitness and Sports.

results.title: Coping with exam anxiety
results.brief_description: A discussion about the ways in which anxiety and stress before exams, coupled with poor study techniques can adversely affect exams results. Demonstrates a number of techniques for the control of anxiety which will enable students to achieve peak examination performance.

results.title: Cook's First Journey
results.brief_description:
This film depicts Captain Cook sailing and discovering new lands, meeting the natives and subsequently returning home.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Controlling quality is everybody's business
results.creator_credit: Wallace J. Richardson and Industrial Education Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the need for a sound working knowledge of the principles of effective quality control, and how these may be applied. The film also dramatises the importance of maintaining good quality, and shows how everyone can help.

results.title: Reinforcement in learning and extinction
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and Herbert Kerkow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Shows how learning is reinforced through stimulus-responses and extinguished when not reinforced, but rapidly reacquired when once more reinforced. Pigeons are used to demonstrate this learning process through responding through such stimuli as a hole in the wall, food, buzzer, and light. Removal of rewards makes them “forget” and return of reward reintroduces the learning almost immediately.
